step.name: Let's do some data science.
step.text: In the last tutorial, we imported a dataset and ran a process. We found out that 349 passengers survived the Titanic accident. Let's build a Process to see if those survivors have something in common or not.

step.name: Retrieve the Titanic Training data.

tasks.task: Drag the Titanic Training data from the Samples repository into the Process panel.

step.info: You have defined the first operation of your process. Now we will learn how easy it is to build a machine learning model on this data.

step.name: Build a decision tree.
step.text: Decision Trees are a popular statistical modeling technique that finds hidden patterns in the data. Letâ€™s build one!

tasks.task: Find the Operators panel on the left.
Open the folder Modeling, Predictive, and finally Trees.
Drag in the Decision Tree operator and drop it after Retrieve Titanic Training.

step.info: Good, we now have the operator in the process but we still need to connect the two operations and define what we want to see as output before we can run it.

step.name: Connect & execute.
step.text: The Decision Tree operator will build a Decision Tree for us based on our Titanic Training data. We still need to connect these operators together to build a Process, though:

tasks.task: Connect the output port ("out") of Retrieve Titanic Training with the input port ("tra" for "training") of Decision Tree. You can click on the ports, or you can drag on them!
Connect the first output ("mod") of the Decision Tree with the result port ("res") on the right side of the Process panel.
Press the 16/media_play.png Run button in the toolbar to execute the process.

step.info: Great job! Your process should now be complete and deliver a decision tree model, which explains to you what most of the survivors and most of the victims had in common.

step.name: Congratulations!
step.text: Great - you just have built your first machine learning model. This was not hard, was it? You now know how to load data, add a machine learning model to the process, and execute both steps.
step.info: From our resulting decision-tree, we can clearly see that survival was not coincidental at all. In fact, it tells us that as a female passenger, with a small family, you were really lucky - at least if you were holding an expensive ticket!
step.text: These tutorials have only shown you the tip of the iceberg of what you can do with RapidMiner. To keep learning and become a RapidMiner Master, click the link below to start the next tutorial.
